page_analysis.text_content:
Accessory structures
(other than 2nd-dwelling units)

The code accommodates a wide variety of choices regarding accessory structures while utilizing parameters like setbacks and the daylight plane to preserve the characteristics of a residential neighborhood as well as privacy and daylight to each lot.

Code sections
Page 30–31
18.12.080
Page 32
18.12.080 (b) (4)

Accessory structure standards (non-dwelling)

There are no minimum lot size requirements for non-dwelling accessory structures.
The regulations are as follows:

All accessory structures...
• Must have a use that is incidental to main dwelling
• Must be detached and at least 3’ from main dwelling
• May NOT have a kitchen
• Count toward the total lot coverage
• If over 120 sf, require a building permit and count towards total gross floor area

Accessory structures located in the buildable area....
• Are subject to the same height and daylight plane regulations as the main dwelling

Accessory structures located in the required setback.....
• May not be located in the front yard
• May not be located in the street-side yard
• May not be located in the rear yard of a through lot
• May not cover more than 50% of the rear yard
• May not be used for sleeping or living
• Are subject to the accessory-structure height and daylight plane regulations (see Figs 25-26 on p. 32)
• May NOT have a kitchen
• Count toward the total lot coverage
• If over 120 sf, require a building permit and count towards total gross floor area
• If over 200 sf, may have no more than two plumbing fixtures

Note: Accessory structures less than 120 sf do not require a building permit but must still comply with all zoning regulations

visual_elements.description: Gray vertical sidebar on left side of page containing the heading 'Accessory structures (other than 2nd-dwelling units)', a descriptive paragraph about the code accommodating a wide variety of choices regarding accessory structures, and code section references at the bottom.
Gray horizontal box near top center containing bold text: 'There are no minimum lot size requirements for non-dwelling accessory structures. The regulations are as follows:'

Three bullet lists detailing regulations for: 'All accessory structures...', 'Accessory structures located in the buildable area....', and 'Accessory structures located in the required setback.....'. Each bullet point lists specific rules and conditions.
Gray rectangular box at bottom right containing the note: 'Note: Accessory structures less than 120 sf do not require a building permit but must still comply with all zoning regulations'.
Empty white rectangular box outlined in gray, positioned to the right of the bullet lists, presumably reserved for figures or diagrams but currently blank.

Must be detached and at least 3’ from main dwelling
Count toward the total lot coverage
If over 120 sf, require a building permit and count towards total gross floor area
Are subject to the same height and daylight plane regulations as the main dwelling
May not be located in the front yard

May not be located in the rear yard of a through lot

May not be used for sleeping or living
Are subject to the accessory-structure height and daylight plane regulations (see Figs 25-26 on p. 32)
If over 200 sf, may have no more than two plumbing fixtures

logical_relationships.expression: All accessory structures must have a use incidental to main dwelling AND be detached at least 3’ from main dwelling AND may NOT have a kitchen AND count toward total lot coverage AND if over 120 sf require a building permit and count towards total gross floor area
Accessory structures located in the buildable area are subject to the same height and daylight plane regulations as the main dwelling

Accessory structures located in the required setback may not be located in the front yard AND may not be located in the street-side yard AND may not be located in the rear yard of a through lot AND may not cover more than 50% of the rear yard AND may not be used for sleeping or living AND are subject to accessory-structure height and daylight plane regulations AND may NOT have a kitchen AND count toward total lot coverage AND if over 120 sf require a building permit and count towards total gross floor area AND if over 200 sf may have no more than two plumbing fixtures

execution_sequence.action: Verify accessory structure use is incidental to main dwelling and detached at least 3 feet
Confirm accessory structure does not have a kitchen and counts toward total lot coverage
If accessory structure is over 120 sf, require building permit and count towards total gross floor area
If accessory structure is located in buildable area, ensure compliance with height and daylight plane regulations
If accessory structure is located in required setback, verify location restrictions, coverage limits, use restrictions, and plumbing fixture limits
